I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 

 
1. 
to Nepal for the Community Irrigation Project. 
 
The project1 will develop or improve small-scale irrigation systems in 12 districts in Nepal 
2. 
through  a  community-driven  process  targeted  at  the  poor,  women,  and  other  disadvantaged 
groups. Small irrigation systems are defined as systems with less than 25 hectares of irrigation 
area in the hills and mountains and less than 200 hectares in the Terai plains. The participating 
districts  were  selected  because  of  their  high  poverty,  food  insecurity  and  irrigation  potential. 
They are Kanchanpur, Kailali, Dang, Kapilvastu in the Terai plains; Doti, Salyan, Rukum, Rolpa, 
Pyuthan  in  the  hills;  and  Bajhang,  Jumla,  Mugu  in  the  mountains.  As  the  first  large-scale 
intervention  in  small  irrigation  development  in  Nepal,  the  project  will  demonstrate  participatory 
irrigation  planning  and  management  and  build  the  capacity  of  all  levels  of  the  government  for 
small-scale  irrigation  development.  Farmers  will  form  or  strengthen  existing  water  users 
associations (WUAs) to apply for project support. The project will provide support to rehabilitate 
and  build new  surface water  irrigation  schemes  and  to  develop  groundwater  irrigation  through 
shallow  tube  wells.  It  will  also  facilitate  access  to  microfinance  support  and  provide  extension 
services.  For  farmers  without  access  to  electricity  who  are  installing  shallow  tube  wells,  the 
project  will  connect  them  to  the  electricity  network.  WUAs  will  in  turn  learn  to  manage  water 
more efficiently and equitably, maintain their systems, and apply improved agricultural practices.  
 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Food security in Nepal is alarmingly low, with 49% of children under 5 years old stunted, 
25%  severely  stunted,  13%  wasted,  and  3%  severely  wasted.  The  majority  of  small  and 
marginal  farmers  cannot  achieve  their  productivity  potential  since  they  have  unreliable  or  no 
access to irrigation water and improved agricultural technology. Small farmers without irrigation 
include the disadvantaged Dalit, Janajati and Muslim populations who live and cultivate rain-fed 
land in peripheral water-scarce areas on steep slopes away from fertile and water-rich valleys in 
the hills and on the fringes of irrigation systems in the plains. Irrigation is key to increasing the 
production  of  staple  crops  to  meet  the  growing  gap  between  agricultural  production  and  the 
needs  of  the  expanding  population  and  to  diversifying  and  intensifying  agriculture  to  increase 
on-farm  incomes,  reduce  rural  poverty,  and  increase  food  security.  Irrigation  therefore  has  a 
critical role to play in Nepal„s poverty reduction and food security strategies. For individuals and 
households,  access  to  irrigation  reduces  the  severity  of  rural  poverty  by  increasing  (i)  food 
production, (ii) on-farm employment, and (iii) incomes.   
 
4. 
The project is in Nepal's confirmed project pipeline for  Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
assistance  and  addresses  the  three  pillars  of  ADB's  country  partnership  strategy,  2010–2012:  
(i)  broad-based  and  inclusive  economic  growth,  (ii)  inclusive  social  development,  and  
(iii) governance and capacity building. It builds on lessons learned from past assistance in the 
agriculture  and  natural  resources  sector 2  and  complements  the  interventions  of  other 
development  partners. 3  The  project  supports  the  multisector  approach  advocated  in  ADB's 

                                                
1  A project preparatory technical assistance grant of $700,000 was provided.  
2  See Summary Sector Assessment (Appendix 2). 
3  See Development Coordination (Appendix 2). 

 2 

Outputs 

Impact and Outcome 

Operational Plan for Sustainable Food Security, as it aims to improve water productivity, access 
to  microfinance,  and  the  application  of  improved  agricultural  practices. 4  The  project's 
interventions  will  be  underpinned  by  associated  capacity  building  at  district  and  community 
levels.  
 
B. 
 
5. 
The  design  and  monitoring  framework  is  in  Appendix  1.  The  expected  impact  of  the 
project  will  be  to  increase  the  agricultural  income of  the rural  poor  and socially  disadvantaged 
groups  in  Nepal.5 The  project  will  contribute  to  Nepal's  goal  of  increasing  agriculture  GDP  per 
capita and the area under irrigation.  
 
The  outcome  of  the  project  will  be  that  the  poor,  women,  and  other  disadvantaged 
6. 
farmers  in  target  communities  will  intensify  and  diversify  agricultural  practices  toward  higher-
value  crops.  With  efficient  utilization,  more  reliable  and  available  irrigation  water,  acquired 
irrigated  agricultural  skills,  and  better  access  to  production  inputs,  crop  yields  are  expected  to 
increase by at least 15% in the subprojects within 5 years of construction. The project will add 
17,000  ha  (4,000  ha  in  hills  and  mountains,  and  13,000  ha  in  the  Terai)  of  improved  or  new 
irrigated area. 
 
C. 
 
7. 
To  achieve  its  expected  outcome,  the  project  will  have  three  outputs:  (i)  WUAs  will 
efficiently manage improved irrigation infrastructure; (ii) participating farmers will apply improved 
agriculture practices and have access to microfinance; and (iii) government capacity to plan and 
coordinate small-scale irrigation projects will be enhanced. 
 
8. 
Improved irrigation infrastructure. The project will respond to requests from WUAs to 
improve  or  provide  new  small-scale  irrigation  infrastructure.  This  may  include  (i)  the 
rehabilitation and extension of existing farmer-managed or new surface water irrigation systems,  
(ii) pond or tank systems with reticulated pipe conveyance and distribution systems, (iii) pumped 
(or “lift”) irrigation systems, and (iv) shallow tube wells.  The project aims to improve water use 
efficiency  and  productivity  within  customary  water  withdrawal  practices  through  improved 
conveyance  and  use  of  micro-irrigation  and  water  conservation  technologies.  The  project  will 
strengthen WUAs  so  they  represent  all  stakeholders  within  the  command  area.  It  will  improve 
their ability to manage their irrigation systems and cope with socioeconomic changes. WUAs will 
be  helped  to  prepare  water  management  plans  to  ensure  equitable,  adequate,  and  efficient 
distribution of irrigation water.  
 
9. 
Improved agriculture practices and access to microfinance. Support will be provided 
to improve farmers' access to inputs and markets, and to enhance their production skills so they 
can increase their cropping intensity and yields. The project will facilitate access to microcredit 
for  agricultural 
infrastructure  operation  and 
maintenance by enabling local microfinance organizations to offer savings and credit services in 
subproject  areas.  Supplementary  capacity  development  will  be  targeted  at  disadvantaged 
groups  to  enable  their  effective  participation.  The  project  will  also  strengthen  links  with  other 
programs relevant for their needs. 

irrigation  equipment,  and 

irrigation 

inputs, 

                                                
4 ADB. 2009. Operational Plan for Sustainable Food Security. Manila.  
5 This  is  one  of  the  outcomes  in  the  Nepal  country  partnership  strategy,  2010–2012  for  the  agriculture  and  natural 

resources sector.  

 

  
10. 
Government  capacity  building.  Although  the  executing  agency  is  experienced  in 
managing  rural  roads  and  other  local  infrastructure  projects,  and  has  strong  oversight  and 
working  relationships  with  district  development  committees  (DDCs)  and  their  district  technical 
offices  (DTOs),  both  the  Department  of  Local  Infrastructure  Development  and  Agricultural 
Roads  (DOLIDAR)  and  the  DDCs  will  be  managing  small  irrigation  services  on  a  large-scale 
basis for the first time. Capacity development will therefore be a major thrust of the project.6 The 
DTOs  will  acquire  new  and  upgraded  skills  in  small-scale  irrigation  design  and  project 
implementation,  and  DDCs  and  community  leaders  will  learn  how  to  plan  and  manage 
subproject selection and implementation effectively and transparently and to target activities at 
the poor, women, and the disadvantaged. 
 
D. 
 
11.

 E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

13. 
During  implementation,  the  DDCs  of  the  participating  districts  will  rank  and  select 
participating ilaka (subdistricts). Project staff will then work with the leaders of the selected ilaka 
to  identify  potential  subprojects  based  on  agreed  selection  criteria.7 The  subproject  selection 
and implementation process is described in detail in the project administration manual (PAM).8 
 
14. 
The  Ministry  of  Local  Development  (MLD)  through  DOLIDAR  will  be  the  executing 
agency for the project. The DDCs and the Rural Microfinance Development Center (RMDC) will 
be  the  implementing  agencies.  DOLIDAR  will  establish  a  project  coordination  unit  (PCU). 
Irrigation  engineers  will  be  engaged  to  enable  the  DTOs  to  serve  as  public  engineers  and  to 
head the DTO units for Irrigation and Other Infrastructure. For consulting services, one package 
will be required of a joint venture between a nongovernment organization(s) and an engineering 
firm(s).  The  consulting  joint  venture  will  assist  the  PCU  at  the  central  level  in  monitoring 
progress and providing and overseeing preparatory and implementation technical assistance. It 
will  also  provide  implementation  technical  assistance  at  the  district  and  community  levels.  In 
addition, two consultants will be engaged as individuals. DDCs and their DTOs and the district 
agriculture  development  offices  will  be  responsible  for  coordinating  implementation  in  their 
respective  districts.  Civil  works  will  be  procured  through  a  combination  of  community 
procurement (through WUAs), shopping, and national competitive bidding. All procurement will 
be carried out in accordance with ADB‟s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time 
to  time)  and  consultants  will  be  recruited  in  line  with  ADB‟s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
15. 
the PAM.9 
 

The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 3 and described in detail in 

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

A. 

Technical  

16.  Many  farmer-managed  surface  irrigation  systems  suffer  from  low  yields  because  of 
fragile diversion structures made of earth, logs, or brushwood and frequently washed away by 
floods  and  rudimentary  distribution  systems  leading  to  an  unreliable  water  supply,  and  high 
distribution loss and operation and maintenance costs. The project will support the participatory 
detailed design and construction of infrastructure, including diversion structures, cross-drainage 
works, improved and extended canal systems, and flood protection facilities to be operated by 
the  WUA.  It  will  not  use  complex  structures  requiring  expensive  materials  as  repairs  may  be 
beyond  the  means  of  the  community,  making  such  structures  unsustainable.  Even  if  they  are 
well  designed,  complex  structures  may  fail  because  of  poor  construction  quality,  landslides, 
earth tremors, or unusual floods. In contrast, structures built from local materials, although they 
may regularly suffer damage and require significant labor inputs for maintenance, can generally 
be  repaired  by  communities  themselves.  The  relative  merits  and  ease  of  maintenance  of 
structures will be assessed on a case-by-case basis. For groundwater irrigation, technology that 
has proven to be successful in the Terai will be used. The project will ensure that the WUAs are 
informed  about  the  appropriate  technology  for  installing  shallow  tube  wells  and  that  they  are

 able to operate and maintain the pumps. The Nepal Electricity Authority will oversee installation 
of new transformers and the expansion of 11kV line to the shallow tube wells.

B. 

Economic and Financial 

The  economic  and financial  analyses10 focused  on  the  economic feasibility  of the  three 
17. 
sample  subprojects.  Quantified  benefits  were  assessed  by  comparing  future  “without  project” 
production  with  the  production  expected  after  the  introduction  of  a  new or  improved  and more 
reliable  irrigation  water  supply,  the  “with  project”  case.  The  economic  internal  rate  of  return 
(EIRR) for the three sample surface water subprojects were estimated to be 20.4%, 17.7%, and 
19.1%.  In  general,  the  sensitivity  results  showed  that  the  EIRRs  remain  acceptable  with 
changes  in the main cost  and  benefit  variables.  As  most  of  the  shallow  tube wells  will  involve 
the conversion of 100% of the command area from rainfed to irrigated cultivation, the economic 

                                                
10  See Financial and Economic Analyses (Appendix 2).  

5 

 

 6 

 

analysis  indicates  that  all  shallow  tube  well  schemes  would  be  economically  viable,  even  with 
new electricity grid connections.  
 
18. 
The project is expected to benefit up to 22,400 farm households, at least 60% of which 
will  have  landholdings  of  less  than  1  ha  in  the  Terai  or  0.5  ha  in  the  hills  and  mountains. 
Incremental  agricultural  production  is  expected  to  total  23,200  tons  of  stable  cereal  crops  and 
29,000 tons of vegetable cash crops. Profits from the improved irrigated crop production can be 
used to finance the long-term operation, maintenance and sustainability of the systems. 

 
Governance 

C. 

to 

for 

infrastructure 

the  participating  districts;  (ii)  enhancing 

19. 
The project supports local governance, financial and administrative decentralization, and 
oversight  of  public  development  expenditure  by  (i)  transferring  the  project's  capital  investment 
funds 
transparency  and 
accountability of public service delivery of small irrigation development  by DDCs by identifying 
and  managing  subprojects  by  local  government  units  and  irrigation  communities;  and  
(iii) building the capacity of WUAs and district governments in financial discipline, responsibility, 
transparency and accountability. A risk assessment and risk management plan is included in the 
linked documents.11 The project aims to support the post-conflict approach outlined in the CPS 
by identifying and managing potential conflict risks and opportunities.12 
 
20. 
ADB‟s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  DOLIDAR,  and  key  measures  to  prevent  corruption  have  been  included  in  the  project 
design.  These  include  procedures  for  social  audit,  enhanced  oversight  of  civil  works 
procurement  processes,  training  in  anticorruption  activities  at  central,  district,  and  local  levels, 
and disclosure of procurement-related information, including contract awards.13 
 
D. 

Poverty, Social and Gender 

21. 
Farmers  with marginal  land  holdings  of  less  than 0.5  ha  or  with less than 1  ha  in poor 
areas  are  targeted  as  beneficiaries  under  the  project.  The  targeting  criteria  of  land  size  and 
poverty incidence correspond to areas with greater numbers of marginalized and poor farmers 
from  disadvantaged  castes  and  ethnic  groups  and  women  farmers.  The  project  will  provide 
supplementary  assistance  to  the  poorest  and  most  socially  marginalized  irrigation  users  to 
increase  participation  and  the  benefits  they  receive.  Through  irrigation  improvements,  social 
mobilization,  the  provision  of  agricultural  services,  and  facilitation  to  access  microfinance 
services,  the  project  will  improve  rural  livelihoods  and  boost  agricultural  production.  The 
intensification  of  irrigated  agriculture,  a  shift  from  rain-fed  to  irrigated  agriculture  and  the 
introduction  of  or  increase  in  vegetable  farming  will  lift  most  marginal  farmers  within  the 
subproject  command  areas  above  the  poverty  line.  The  economic  analysis  conducted  for  the 
project pilot subprojects estimated that the project will increase incomes by $100–$300 a year 
for small and marginal farmers, i.e. those 85-95% of households which have less than 2.5 ha. 
The project will also contribute to the achievement of the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) 
directly    by  improving  food  security  (MDG1)  and  indirectly  through  higher  incomes  and  food 
production  (MDGs  2–7).  The  landless  poor  will  benefit  only  indirectly  from  irrigation 
improvements;  however  these  households  will  benefit  from  access  to  microfinance.  The 
summary poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 2.  
                                                
11  See Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (Appendix 2).  
12 See  Nepal  Post-Conflict  Sensitive  Approach:  A  Peace  Building  Tool  (Peace  Filter)  for  Project  Design  and 

Implementation (Appendix 2). 

13  See also Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (Appendix 2).  

  
The  project  is  classified  as  having  a  gender  equity  theme.  A  gender  action  plan14 has 
22. 
been  made  an  integral  part  of  the  project  design  and  is  covered  by  one  of  the  covenants.    It 
includes  (i)  gender-sensitive  and 
inclusive  procedures  and  provisions  within  WUAs;  
(ii)  meaningful  consultation  and  participation  of  women  and  consequent  incorporation  of 
women‟s needs in the system design and other project activities through implementation of the 
consultation  and  participation  plan; 15 (iii)  proportionate  representation  of  women  in  decision 
making bodies and processes, training, and project activities; (iv) extra capacity building prior to 
participation in training, WUAs, and decision making; (v) equal payment to women for labor (and 
equal treatment for voluntary labor); (vi) a sex-, caste-, and ethnicity-disaggregated monitoring 
and  management  information  system;  (vii)  subproject-specific  application  of  the  gender  action 
plan;  (viii)  microfinance  schemes  for  women  that  will  provide  them  with  access  to  loans  and 
savings to improve their agricultural livelihoods. 
 
E. 

Safeguards 

Environment:  Category  B.  The  environmental  assessment16 indicates  that  minimal  or 
23. 
no  significant  environmental  impacts  are  expected  in  most  subprojects.  Each  subproject  is 
subject to environmental and social screening at the pre-feasibility stage to avoid such adverse 
impacts  as  encroaching  on  the  habitats  of  endangered  indigenous  peoples,  historical  and 
cultural  sites,  or  protected  and  ecologically  sensitive  areas,  or  locating  the  system  in  an  area 
with vulnerable slopes. An environmental assessment and review framework has been prepared. 
It calls for environmental due diligence to be conducted on all subprojects at the pre-feasibility 
stage, and for an initial environmental examination with an environmental management plan to 
be  prepared  for  any  surface  water  schemes  with  a  command  area  of  more  than  150  ha.  For 
surface water rehabilitation schemes and groundwater cluster schemes, a due diligence report 
will  be  prepared.  The  list  of  potential  environmental  impacts,  their  mitigation  measures, 
institutional arrangements for implementation and monitoring of any environmental management 
plans,  and  the  outlines  for  the  initial  environmental  examination  and  environmental  due 
diligence report have been described in the environmental assessment and review framework. 
Should  an  environmental  impact  assessment  be  triggered  for  a  particular  subproject,  it  will  be 
dropped.  
 
24. 
ADB  has  assessed  the  sustainability  of  water  resources  and  determined  that  the  draw 
on  both  surface  water  and  groundwater  under  the  project  is  minimal  and  is  not  expected  to 
significantly  impact  the  water  balance.  A  disaster  and  climate  change  risks  screening17 was 
conducted  to  assess  project  exposure  to  climate-induced  risk  and  natural  disasters.  Climate 
change projections indicate that Nepal is more likely to suffer  increased drought in future. The 
project will help farmers adapt to long periods of drought through improved irrigation and water 
use  efficiency  in  subproject  areas.  In  addition,  the  project's  social  mobilization  and  capacity 
development  program  will  help  both  farmer  beneficiaries  and  the  project  engineers  better 
understand  the  impacts  of  the  environment  on  the  project  and  to  identify  risk  reduction 
measures  such  as  on-farm  water  conservation  and  management  and  landslide  control 
techniques. A greater incidence of flash floods is also expected during the monsoon period. The 
project  will  promote  flexible  irrigation  diversion  structures  and  build  the  technical  and financial 
capacity of the WUAs to maintain the improved irrigation structures. 
 
                                                
14 Gender Action Plan (Appendix 2). 
15 Consultation and Participation Plan (Appendix 2). 
16  See Environmental Assessment and Measures (Appendix 2). 
17  See Disaster and Climate Change Risks Screen Results (Appendix 2). 

7 

 

 for  subproject 

functioning  WUA 

Involuntary  Resettlement:  Category  C.  A  resettlement 

framework  has  been 
25. 
prepared. 18  The  resettlement  framework  covers  small,  community-led  subprojects  with  no 
resettlement and where all land acquisition is voluntary. The selection criteria for a subproject is 
that irrigation improvement is desired by a community whose members would voluntarily donate 
small  parcels  of  their  land  for  the  irrigation  enhancement.  By  contributing  land  for  the  project 
they  become  primary  beneficiaries  of  enhanced  irrigation  facility.  For  each  subproject  with 
requirements  for  new  land,  procedures  have  been  established  to  verify  that  the  land  is  being 
provided  voluntarily  by  those  who  stand  to  gain  directly,  and  to  verify  that  the  subproject  will 
cause  no  impoverishment  or  displacement  of  tenants  or  bonded  labor.  Resettlement  due 
diligence  will  also  ensure  that  meaningful  consultation  has  taken  place  in  good  faith  with  all 
affected  persons,  a 
implementation  exists,  and  sex-
disaggregated  socioeconomic  baseline  data  have  been  collected.  This  resettlement  due 
diligence will be documented in the subproject feasibility study report. Any subproject requiring 
nonvoluntary land acquisition will be dropped.  
 
26. 
Indigenous  Peoples:  Category  B.  An  indigenous  peoples  planning  framework  has 
been  prepared  based  on  an  analysis  of  indigenous  peoples'  impacts  and  vulnerabilities.19 The 
analysis  considered  different  categories  of 
(endangered,  highly 
marginalized, marginalized, disadvantaged and advantaged), as well as their traditional rights to 
water  sources,  land  and  forest  resources,  and  caste  groups  that  do  not  receive  sufficient 
benefits  under  existing  arrangements.  The  inclusion  of  indigenous  peoples  in  subprojects  is 
expected  to  be  high,  as  the  project  targets  geographically  marginal  rural  areas  where 
indigenous peoples are a majority. The analysis indicated that indigenous peoples in the sample 
subproject  areas  are  not  vulnerable  according  the  definition  in  ADB‟s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement.  Therefore  it  is  expected  that  the  project  will  impact  indigenous  peoples  only  in  a 
positive way. The project design incorporates many features that will ensure indigenous peoples 
are able to benefit and participate meaningfully. Subprojects are community-driven and will not 
be  prepared  unless requested by  the  community,  and  unless they  meet  screening  criteria  that 
include a requirement that the community is able to form an inclusive community mechanism for 
implementation. The selection criteria will ensure that subprojects will not affect the habitats of 
endangered  indigenous  peoples  and  areas  where  there  is  a  dispute  over  water  user  rights. 
Issues  of  gender,  participation  and  land  acquisition  are  dealt  with  under  the  project  gender 
action  plan,  the  resettlement  framework,  and  the  consultation  and  participation  plan.  The 
indigenous  peoples  planning  framework  summarizes  the  strategy  for  participation  and 
realization  of  project  benefits,  specifically  enhancing  participation  by  indigenous  peoples, 
screening  for  negative  impacts  and  ensuring  benefits,  institutional  arrangements,  and 
monitoring and evaluation. 
 
F. 

Risks and Mitigating Measures 

indigenous  peoples 

27.  Major risks and mitigating measures are summarized in Table 4 and described in detail 
in the risk assessment and risk management plan.20 
 

                                                
18  See Involuntary Resettlement Assessment and Measures (Appendix 2). 
19  See Indigenous Peoples Assessment and Measures (Appendix 2). 
20  Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (Appendix 2).  

8 

 

 Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures 

Risks 
Public Financial Management. Public 
financial management capacity in DDCs 
is weak. 
Procurement. 
in 
procurement  controls  at  DDCs  threaten 
transparency or effectiveness. 

Weaknesses 

Mitigating Measures 
DOLIDAR, with the support of the international joint 
venture, will provide implementation support, 
including financial management training. 
The DOLIDAR PCU will conduct random but regular 
reviews of contracts awarded by the DDCs; MLD will 
ensure that DDCs that are not complying with the 
applicable procurement procedures take appropriate 
remedial action.     

ADB will conduct random reviews of contracts 
awarded for civil works and supply of materials 
(except for the first contracts in each district which 
will be reviewed before they are awarded); contracts 
with misprocurement will not be eligible for grant 
financing.   
DOLIDAR will assign a project-dedicated irrigation 
engineer to the DTO of each district to monitor the 
performance of contractors, suppliers and WUAs.  

Random and independent spot checks will be 
undertaken by the PCU. The National Vigilance 
Center will conduct technical audits of subprojects. 

ADB review missions will conduct spot checks of 
contractor and WUA performance. 
A significant part of the civil works will be undertaken 
through community contracts awarded to WUAs. 

MLD will engage with the political parties and DDC 
officials to maintain political support for the 
anticorruption agenda. 
Community contracting will be used where possible. 
A WUA monitoring committee will oversee 
subproject construction works.  

Project field teams will monitor the bidding. 

Training on ADB's anticorruption policy will be 
provided for project staff during inception and review 
missions. 

Upon the recommendation of DOLIDAR, PPMO to 
blacklist contractors and suppliers proven to be 
involved in malfeasance.     

Oversight  and  monitoring  of  performance 
of  contractors,  suppliers,  and  WUAs  by 
the DDCs Is inadequate.  

Corruption.  Politicians  and  officials 
interfere in project implementation 

Bidding of facilities and services is 
subject to malfeasance. Potential risks 
include imposition of informal conditions, 
kickbacks by officials, bid rigging, 
collusion, fraud, and deviations from 
original bid documents. 

ADB  =  Asian  Development  Bank,  DDC  =  district  development  committee,  DOLIDAR  =  Department  of  Local 
Infrastructure  Development  and  Agricultural  Roads,  DTO  =  district  technical  office,  MLD  =  Ministry  of  Local 
Development, PCU = project coordinating unit, PPMO = Public Procurement Monitoring Organization, WUA = 
water users associations.  
Source:  Nepal:  Governance  Risk  Assessment  prepared  for  the  Country  Partnership  Strategy,  August  2009; 
Asian Development Bank. 

 

IV. 

ASSURANCES 

The  government  and  the  MLD  have  assured  ADB  that  implementation  of  the  project 
28. 
shall conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement, as described in detail 
in the project administration manual and grant documents. 

9 

 

 The government  and  MLD  have  agreed  with  ADB  on  certain  covenants for  the  project, 

 
29. 
which are set forth in the grant agreement and project agreement. 
 
 

V. 

RECOMMENDATION 

30. 
I am satisfied that the proposed grant would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and,  acting  in  the  absence  of  the  President,  under  the 
provisions  of  Article  35.1  of  the  Articles  of  Agreement  of  ADB,  I  recommend  that  the  Board 
approve the grant not exceeding $26,400,000 to Nepal from ADB‟s Special Funds resources for 
the  Community  Irrigation  Project,  on  terms  and conditions  that  are  substantially  in accordance 
with those set forth in the draft grant agreement and project agreement presented to the Board. 
 
 
 
 

C. Lawrence Greenwood 
Vice-President 

 
 
3 September 2010

Output 1. WUAs efficiently manage improved irrigation infrastructure 
 1.1 Irrigation infrastructure improvement 

Batch 1 Subprojects (January 2012– April 2013) 
Batch 2 Subprojects (January 2013 – April 2014) 
Batch 3 Subprojects (January 2014 – April 2015) 
Batch 4 Subprojects (January 2015 – April 2016) 

1.2  Capacity building of WUAs to maintain irrigation infrastructure and manage 

equitable water distribution and preparation of O&M and water management plans  
(February 2012 – July 2017) 

1.3  Training support and associated field demonstrations to farmers in  micro-irrigation 
application techniques to optimize productivity of water ( March 2012 – July 2017) 

 
Output 2. Participating farmers apply improved agriculture and micro-finance practices  
2.1  Short courses and associated field demonstrations to impart  irrigated crop 

husbandry skills to farmers (March 2013 – July 2017)   

2.2.Establishment of  farmer field schools on each subproject operating for 1 year on 

production packages for cereal and high value crops  (2012 – 2017) 

2.3 Training of trainers (district Level)  for cereal crop seed selection; vegetable 

seedling production; nursery management; off season vegetable production; soil 
management; weed and pest control (2012–2013) 

2.4 Capacity building of local MFIs to service farmers with input loans (January 2012– 

December 2015) 

2.5 Provision of matching grants to WUAs who deposit within first year after subproject 
construction, annual collections of non-recurrent maintenance funds in accounts at 
local MFI (April 2013–February 2017)   

 
Output 3: Government capacity to plan and coordinate small-scale irrigation projects is 
enhanced 
3.1  Orientation training for DTO and PCU engineers on appropriate small irrigation 

infrastructure design  (December 2011–January 2012)  

3.2  Training for DADOs (February 2012) 
3.3  District rapid assessments for irrigation potential in areas categorized as 

disadvantaged ( September–October 2011)

(November–December 2011) 

December  2011–2014)

2012 to July 2017)
